items.title: IPv4Obj() and IPv6Obj() cannot use __eq__() and __neq__() operations with some Python objects
items.body:
Code like this (below) fails at logical comparison operators (==, or !=) if the argument is a string:

```python
from ciscoconfparse.ccp_util import IPv4Obj

addr_obj = IPv4Obj("10.0.0.1/24")
## Error caused by '!= ""', below:
if addr_obj != "":
    print("ERROR: addr_obj is not an empty string")
```

Result:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File testme.py", line 4, in <module>
    if addr_obj!="":
  File "/home/mpennington/venv/py37_u18/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ciscoconfparse/ccp_util.py", line 285, in __eq__
    raise ValueError(errmsg)
ValueError: '<IPv4Obj 10.0.0.1/24>' cannot compare itself to '': 'str' object has no attribute 'as_decimal'
```

IPv4Obj() and IPv6Obj() instances should be able to use `__eq__()` and `__neq__()` operations with any other Python object type.

items.title: Broken regex in has_ip_pim methods
items.body:
Hey,

All 3 pim-related methods of `ciscoconfparse.models_cisco.IOSIntfLine` crash due to broken regexes. Sample output:

```
[ins] In [324]: type(i)
Out[324]: ciscoconfparse.models_cisco.IOSIntfLine

[ins] In [320]: i.has_ip_pim_sparse_mode
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
error                                     Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-320-a7308031a23a> in <module>
----> 1 i.has_ip_pim_sparse_mode

~/git/.direnv/python-3.7.4/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ciscoconfparse/models_cisco.py in has_ip_pim_sparse_mode(self)
   1075             r'^\s*ip\spim\ssparse-mode\s*$)\s*$',
   1076             result_type=bool,
-> 1077             default=False)
   1078         return retval
   1079

~/git/.direnv/python-3.7.4/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ciscoconfparse/ccp_abc.py in re_match_iter_typed(self, regex, group, result_type, default, untyped_default, recurse)
    654         if recurse is False:
    655             for cobj in self.children:
--> 656                 mm = re.search(regex, cobj.text)
    657                 if not (mm is None):
    658                     return result_type(mm.group(group))

~/git/.direnv/python-3.7.4/lib/python3.7/re.py in search(pattern, string, flags)
    181     """Scan through string looking for a match to the pattern, returning
    182     a Match object, or None if no match was found."""
--> 183     return _compile(pattern, flags).search(string)
    184
    185 def sub(pattern, repl, string, count=0, flags=0):

~/git/.direnv/python-3.7.4/lib/python3.7/re.py in _compile(pattern, flags)
    284     if not sre_compile.isstring(pattern):
    285         raise TypeError("first argument must be string or compiled pattern")
--> 286     p = sre_compile.compile(pattern, flags)
    287     if not (flags & DEBUG):
    288         if len(_cache) >= _MAXCACHE:

~/git/.direnv/python-3.7.4/lib/python3.7/sre_compile.py in compile(p, flags)
    762     if isstring(p):
    763         pattern = p
--> 764         p = sre_parse.parse(p, flags)
    765     else:
    766         pattern = None

~/git/.direnv/python-3.7.4/lib/python3.7/sre_parse.py in parse(str, flags, pattern)
    942     if source.next is not None:
    943         assert source.next == ")"
--> 944         raise source.error("unbalanced parenthesis")
    945
    946     if flags & SRE_FLAG_DEBUG:

error: unbalanced parenthesis at position 28
```
I assume these lines:

```
            r'^\s*ip\spim\sdense-mode\s*$)\s*$',
            r'^\s*ip\spim\ssparse-mode\s*$)\s*$',
            r'^\s*ip\spim\ssparse-dense-mode\s*$)\s*$',
```
should be replaced by something like:
```
            r'^\s*ip\spim\sdense-mode\s.*$',
            r'^\s*ip\spim\ssparse-mode\s.*$',
            r'^\s*ip\spim\ssparse-dense-mode\s.*$',
```

I have not tested it yet, though. I can check it tomorrow and submit a pull request.

items.title: The keyword formerly called `all_children` is now called `recurse`
items.body:
CiscoConfParse has methods named `find_objects_w_all_children()`; using a keyword called `all_children` with that method looks wrong.

I do not like breaking API changes; however, starting with CiscoConfParse version 1.4.0, `recurse` will replace the keyword called `all_children`.

I apologize in advance for the inconvenience and potentially breaking scripts.

items.title: Find Cisco IOS Macro blocks
items.body:
Hello and thank you for making a fantastic tool!

I have a need to find and delete macro blocks inside IOS configurations.

Unfortunately Cisco does not indent the child lines inside the macro so the normal child logic will not work.  However all macros do start with a "macro name" line and do end with an "@" alone on a line. 

A nice summary of IOS macros can be found here:  
https://ccie-or-null.net/2011/06/13/working-with-cisco-macros/

Thank you again,

- Brad

items.title: Parsing brace delimited configurations does not preserve line numbers
items.body: The IOSCfgLine objects report the wrong line numbers when using junos syntax. Perhaps a `!` could be added in place of a `}` delimiter so that the configuration line numbers are preserved.

items.title: setup.py: Conditional package dependencies are recorded unconditionally
items.body:
This package uses Python code in _setup.py_ to provide conditional dependencies instead of using metadata settings. On the line 18 in _setup.py_ there is this code:
```
## Conditionally require the correct ipaddr package in Python2 vs Python3
if sys.version_info[0]<3:
    IPADDR = "ipaddr>=2.1.11"
    DNSPYTHON = "dnspython"
else:
    IPADDR = "ipaddress"
    DNSPYTHON = "dnspython3"
```
Thus, depending on the version of Python that the package is built with, some of the dependencies are never recorded.
Here's _requires.txt_ from egg-info in the source distribution (sdist) package from PyPI:
```
ipaddr>=2.1.11
dnspython
colorama
```
Similarly, the _METADATA_ file in the wheel released on PyPI has this:
```
...
Requires-Dist: ipaddr (>=2.1.11)
Requires-Dist: dnspython
Requires-Dist: colorama
```
As you can see in both _requires.txt_ and _METADATA_ files, _dnspython3_ is not recorded, nor are _dnspython_ and _ipaddr_ listed as *conditional* dependencies. They are both included *unconditionally*.
This breaks the installation of the sdist with Python 3 if the sdist is built with Python 2 and the build version *should not* matter.

Instead, the _requires.txt_ file should have this content to be equivalent of the `if` statement above:
```
colorama

[:python_version<'3']
ipaddr>=2.1.11
dnspython

[:python_version>='3']
ipaddress
dnspython3
```
The wheel metadata should have:
```
...
Requires-Dist: ipaddr (>=2.1.11); python_version<'3'
Requires-Dist: dnspython; python_version<'3'
Requires-Dist: colorama
Requires-Dist: ipaddress; python_version>='3'
Requires-Dist: dnspython3; python_version>='3'
```

However, newer versions of _dnspython_ support both Python 2 and 3. So, there's no need for that dependency to be conditional at all. I'm assuming here the full API compatibility and no code changes necessary. Also, _ipaddress_ is in the standard library for Python 3.3+ and there's no need to make that dependency conditional either or have an external dependency at all. Python 3.0, 3.1, and 3.2 are not supported and there's no need to use a 3rd party dependency only for these versions. Also, _ipaddress_ backport could be used conditionally instead of _ipaddr_ with Python<3 to keep code compatibility simpler. Let's assume that this package still uses _ipaddr_, though, since the choice of that package is unrelated to conditional/unconditional dependency problem.

So, the _requires.txt_ should really look like this:
```
colorama
dnspython

[:python_version<'3']
ipaddr>=2.1.11
```

To accomplish that, the _setup.py_ file needs to be changed to replace the `if` statement on lines 19-24 with the following:
```
requires = ['colorama', 'dnspython']
extras_require = {
    ":python_version<'3'": ['ipaddr>=2.1.11'],
}

# Fall back to conditional code only for very old version of setuptools
if int(setuptools.__version__.split('.')[0]) < 18:
    extras_require = {}
    if sys.version_info[0] < 3:
        requires.append('ipaddr>=2.1.11')
```
and have this in the `setup()` call, replacing line 42:
```
install_requires=requires,       # Unconditional dependencies
extras_require=extras_require,  # Conditional dependencies
```
Of course, the fallback code could be omitted if we're sure we're going to build this package with setuptools 18.x or better. In that case we would just have in `setup()`:
```
install_requires=['colorama', 'dnspython'],
extras_require={
    ":python_version<'3'": ['ipaddr>=2.1.11'],
},
```
If we're sure that we can use setuptools-36.x or better, then the new syntax can be used directly in the `install_requires`:
```
install_requires=[
    'colorama',
    'dnspython',
    "ipaddr>=2.1.11; python_version<'3'",
]
```
The other code that prepares `requires` and `extras_require` can be omitted in this case.

Please, see a similar issue here: https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/issues/341 and the corresponding fix: https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/merge_requests/191/diffs

Can we please get this fixed so that the sdist packages released to PyPI can be used by both Python 2 and 3 correctly?

items.title: append_to_family method breaks parent/child relationship two or more levels below
items.body:
Hello,
while working with automating policy maps on a router I have encountered quite a weird behavior - my script was working for one loop, but for anything more it was sticking all the commands to the last child in policy-map instead of one for each class-map. Trying it on much simpler example (modified append_to_family example) the effect was the same:
```
config = [
    '!',
    'interface Serial1/0',
    ' ip address 1.1.1.1 255.255.255.252',
    '  test line 1',
    'interface Serial1/1',
    ]
parse = CiscoConfParse(config)
for obj in parse.find_objects(r'^interface'):
  obj.append_to_family(' carrier-delay msec 500')
```

```
!
interface Serial1/0
 ip address 1.1.1.1 255.255.255.252
 carrier-delay msec 500
  test line 1
interface Serial1/1
 carrier-delay msec 500
```

I think the problem is that it should look for a last child in a block not the first one, for my use I have modified the function in ccp_abc.py file by adding 
```
while len(last_child.children) > 0: last_child = last_child.children[-1]
```
before insert_after function, which now preserves parent/child relationship on lower than one levels:
```
interface Serial1/0
 ip address 1.1.1.1 255.255.255.252
  test line 1
 carrier-delay msec 500
interface Serial1/1
 carrier-delay msec 500
```
which in my opinion is the expected behavior.

items.title: a non-cisco style indent makes nonsense parents/child relationships
items.body:
for example, let me show some configurations to you:
```
#
ip vpn-instance mgt_vrf
 route-distinguisher 2:1
#
 telnet server enable
 telnet server acl 2000
#
 switch-mode normal slot 0
 switch-mode normal slot 1
 switch-mode normal slot 2
 switch-mode normal slot 3
 switch-mode normal slot 4
 switch-mode normal slot 5
```

As we can see, with the second line indented with length 0, all others lines are indented with length 1, with comment character \# separating config block.
But with this kind of config, ciscoConfParse will consider the second line (with indent 0) as the parent config of all other lines, which is not  reasonable at all. when you try to retrieve the childrens node of
```
ip vpn-instance mgt_vrf
```
it will show you all the rest as its children.
The core loop of determining parents and children relationship is in the ciscoconfparse.py
```
            if (indent > 0) and not (parent is None):
                ## Add the line as a child (parent was cached)
                self._add_child_to_parent(retval, idx, indent, parent, obj)
            elif (indent > 0) and (parent is None):
                ## Walk backwards to find parent, and add the line as a child
                candidate_parent_index = idx - 1
                while candidate_parent_index >= 0:
                    candidate_parent = retval[candidate_parent_index]
                    if (candidate_parent.indent<indent) and \
                        candidate_parent.is_config_line:
                        # We found the parent
                        parent = candidate_parent
                        parents[indent] = parent  # Cache the parent
                        if indent == 0:
                            parent.oldest_ancestor = True
                        break
                    else:
                        candidate_parent_index -= 1
```
as you can see, no comment is checked in this loop, so it will cross the border of current config blocks.

items.title: IOS TACACS+ Group raise ValueError when factory set to True
items.body:
Hello
- I have some configuration files with  white space at the end of the string
```
(vim set list showing end of lines as $)
aaa group server tacacs+ tacacs $ <--  white space
    server xx.xx.xx.xx $
    server xx.xx.xx.xx $
    source-interface lolipop$

```

- This  not match the regexp below and raise ValueError as mm is None

```
REGEX = r'^aaa\sgroup\sserver\s(?P<protocol>\S+)\s(?P<group>\S+)$'
```

- What do you think if the regexp was like this ?

```
REGEX = r'aaa\sgroup\sserver\s(?P<protocol>\S+)\s(?P<group>\S+$|\S+)'
Match 1
Full match	0-31	`aaa group server tacacs+ tacacs`
Group `protocol`	17-24	`tacacs+`
Group `group`	25-31	`tacacs`
```
- So code would be something like this:

```

##
##-------------  IOS TACACS+ Group
##
class IOSAaaGroupServerLine(BaseCfgLine):
    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        super(IOSAaaGroupServerLine, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.feature = 'aaa group server'
        REGEX = r'aaa\sgroup\sserver\s(?P<protocol>\S+)\s(?P<group>\S+$|\S+)'  
        # REGEX = r'^aaa\sgroup\sserver\s(?P<protocol>\S+)\s(?P<group>\S+)$'
        mm = re.search(REGEX, self.text)
        if not (mm is None):
            groups = mm.groupdict()
            self.protocol = groups.get('protocol', '')
            self.group = groups.get('group', '')
        else:
            raise ValueError
```

Thank for your work and your support, 
Regards,

items.title: Feature Request: Return boolean on successful save
items.body:
While it may be a trivial thing and possible to check locally, it would be helpful if the `CiscoConfParse.save_as` method were to confirm that the file save was successful and return a boolean.

``` Python
    def save_as(self, filepath):
        """Save a text copy of the configuration at ``filepath``; this
        method uses the OperatingSystem's native line separators (such as
        ``\\r\\n`` in Windows).

        Returns a boolean if writing to file was successful or not"""
        try:
            with open(filepath, 'w') as newconf:
                for line in self.ioscfg:
                    newconf.write(line+'\n')
            return True
        except IOError:
            return False
```

Perhaps returning the exception could be an option for debugging, so if disk space were full or insufficient permissions occurred, the user could troubleshoot and correct the issue?
